data.title: Yaadein (1964)
data.meta_description: The film is soliloquy of a man who comes home to find that his wife and son are not at home, he assumes that they have left him and reminiscences his life with them, and scared of his life without them, he regrets his past indiscretions. The suspense is only revealed in the end.
data.text:
Although sometimes this is an overused statement, I have truly never ever watched anything like Yaadein before. A somewhat forgotten gem of Indian cinema.

Opening with a one shot, we glide through an empty house. Flowing curtains, a storm, strong shadows. One by one we go to each door in the house, and they all close on us. Abandonment is established is the first scene. Then enters our protagonist, a jolly looking man who in the next ten minutes turns out to be very different from his first impression. He is a man of secrets.

From then ensues a slow, dramatic descend of an abandoned man drowning in his memories, to the verge of psychosis. It is both written and…

Now you're gone/They linger on

These memories/All these precious memories

What do we do after a connection with another person is severed? Whether that is because of the end of a relationship, a life or for other reasons, we remember. The good memories of bad times, the bad memories of good times, and vice versa. Is it healthy to hold on to such memories? Maybe not. But what if it's the only way to preserve that person or relationship? The memories hurt, even the happy ones, but what else do we have left? Maybe we should let go, but how could we? And even if we wanted to, can we?

In Yaadein Sunil Dutt deals with such questions, and does…
